levels.label: entry
levels.description: Writing legibly with consistent letter formation, maintaining a steady size and spacing that can be read by others.
levels.example_task: Copy this paragraph in your best handwriting. Focus on keeping your letters the same size and on the line.
levels.example_response: The pupil produces legible handwriting with most letters formed correctly and sitting on the line, though speed is slow and some letter joins are inconsistent.
common_errors: Inconsistent letter sizes, with ascenders and descenders not clearly differentiated
Letters sitting above or below the line rather than on it

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Writing fluently with joined handwriting at a reasonable speed, making choices about when to join and when to leave letters unjoined.
levels.example_task: Write a short paragraph about your weekend. Aim for fluent, joined handwriting. Then label a science diagram underneath using neat, unjoined print.
levels.example_response: The pupil produces joined handwriting for the paragraph at a comfortable pace. For the diagram labels, they switch to clear, unjoined print that is easy to read alongside the drawing.
common_errors: Using joined writing for diagram labels where print would be clearer
Writing very slowly because fluency has not been developed

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Writing legibly, fluently and with increasing speed, making deliberate choices about letter shape, joining, and writing implement based on the task and audience.
levels.example_task: Your teacher sets three tasks: rough notes for a science experiment, a neat copy of a poem for display, and filling in a form with capital letters. Explain how your handwriting approach will differ for each.
levels.example_response: For rough notes, I will write quickly in joined handwriting because speed matters more than neatness and only I need to read them. For the poem display, I will write carefully and neatly, possibly using a calligraphy pen, because it needs to look good for an audience. For the form, I will use unjoined capital letters because forms need clear, separate letters that anyone can read. The standard of handwriting depends on the purpose.
common_errors: Using the same handwriting approach for all tasks without adapting to purpose
Not understanding why unjoined writing is appropriate in some contexts
